title: Legend Grouping
hint:
Legend entries may be grouped. This helps the user to clean up the legend and maintain an overview over all features and classes.

Right-clicking the group header allows the user to delete or rename the group. Here, the group entries can also be linked, to have the same color.

title: Legend Entries
hint:
Each legend entry represents one class or feature.

Its color may be changed by clicking the colored panel.

title: Hiding a Group
hint:
By clicking the little eye icon, the user is able to hide groups from the legend.

Entries that are inside a hidden group have their colorcoding removed. In the tree visualization they appear without a color.

title: Highlighting Entries
hint:
By clicking the little M icon, the user can highlight any one class or feature in the visualization.

For the selected entry, the color is changed to a bright red, while the colorcoding of all other entries is removed. Only one entry can be highlighted at all times.

title: Node: Basic Info
hint:
The most basic node visualization gives some information on the split's feature and location (Sp), the voted class and class distribution (V) and the sample number (S).

Note, how class and feature names are colored according to the legend entries.

title: Node: Pie Charts
hint:
This node visualization illustrates the class distribution at this node as a pie chart. For the sake of simplicity, only the five most abundand classes are shown.

Note, how class colors are related to the legend.

title: Adding a Group
hint: By clicking the "New group" button, the user can add an empty group to the legend. A popup menu requests the groups name so make sure that you browser does not block Forester.

title: Default Colorscale for the Legend
hint:
This option controls the legend's default colorscale. All scales from ColorBrewer can be selected.

When you open a new project in Forester, the scale Pastel 2 is used. The assignment of the colors follows the initial order of the entries in the legend. The first two colors #b3e2cd and #fdcdac are assigned to the first two entries and so on. When there are more entries than colors, the entry is colored white.

title: Layout Settings
hint:
This section controls the layout algorithm that determines positions of the nodes within the tree.

The option Layout Direction determines the flow of the tree. The value may either be top-bottom for vertical or left-right for horizontal placement.

The two options Level and Branch Space determine the distance between levels and branches in the tree. Note, that these settings work in combination with the layout direction.

title: Aligning Leaves at one Level
hint:
By enabling the Dendrogram option, the layout algorithm aligns all leaves at the last level. This improves comparability between leaves and works very well in combination with the Bar Chart Views.

Note, that the dendrogram is much wider than the default layout. We advice to switch to square links between nodes.

title: Link Style
hint:
The option Path style controls the shape of links between nodes. The three values linear, curved and ragged use lines, sigmoidal curves and step functions respectively.

Information regarding the sample number and the class distribution can be encoded in the links. The option Path Flow can be used to encode the sample number in a link. When it is set to linear or scaled the link thickness encodes the number of samples that flow along a path. Based on the value, the number of samples is either scaled linearly or using a algorithm that homogenizes the sample number over many magnitudes. With the value colorcoded, the class distribution is additionally encoded within the link.

title: Previewing and Saving Settings
hint:
Most settings automatically trigger changes within the illustration. This preview is however not persistent. When you close the dialog, the settings are restored to their old values.

Only by clicking the submit button are settings permanently changed. Be careful, Forster is currently missing an Undo feature!

title: Node Context Menu
hint:
Whenever you hover over a node, a context menu appears. Don't underestimate it! Although it is small it is very powerful.

By clicking the gear you can open node-specific settings. They allow you to fine-tune a node's illustration.
Some views do not have changeable settings. For them, the icon is blocked:

With the left and right arrows, you can quickly scroll through all possible views for a node.

title: Applying Settings for Multiple Nodes
hint:
Using the Apply To option, you can update settings for multiple views at once.
  • With the value this, only the settings of the currently targeted node are updated.
  • With subtree this node and all it's children are updated.
  • With view, all nodes that currently use the same view are updated.
  • All obviously updates all nodes of the tree.

Note, that when settings for a view should be applied to a node that currently uses another view, that view is changed. This feature is not previewed and only takes effect when the changes are submitted.
